From, the ". r. Commercial .adrertiser, March 9.


MORGAN.-The following remarks were pre-.
pared to accompany the letter of Capt. Brandt,
published last evening, but were excluded for want
of room AS at this distance from the circle in
which he moves, his character may not be distinct
ly known, Ito quote the Editor of the Quebec
Mercury,) it is but justice, since his name has
been brought forward, to say, that MIR. Brandt is
generally respected and there need be no hesita-
ton in believing what he says lie is well edu-
Gated young man, and was as much esteemed by
the Officers Of the Division of His Majesty's Ar
my, with which he served during the last Amer
ican war, for his gentlemanly manners IN society,
as for his courage and humanity in the field. Mr..
Brandt some time ago visited England, and while
there surprised the public and the poet, Thomas
Campbell, by letter, as crcditable to his tllial


feelings as to his literary attanments in which he
successfully vindicated the character OF his
deceased father, Joseph Brandt. from the asper-
sons cast upon it, without sufficient inquiry, by
Mr.. Campbell, in the beautiful but unfaithful mar
ratvc poem of 6 Gertrude of Wyoming"


Thus, then, every material point of the aledged
discoveries of the celebrated New Ark Conven-
tion, has been successively overthrown. We were
told that Morgan was taken to Niagara and butch
cred, and that Mr.. Chaplin, of Buffalo, was one Of
the murIerers. But the story proved not to be
true: We were told that traces of blood &c.
were found IN Fort Niagara But tnat IS NOT true


We were told that Capt. Brandt was consulted
about killing him, or putting him away; and that
was not true. We have all along been told, more
over, that there was conspiracy originally, to
get Morgan from Batavia, to Canandaigua, on
false accusation OF larceny: And now jury has
solemnly declared that that story was likewise un-
true. And one of the men convicted at Canaan
dagua, was convicted by means of perjury.
gentleman in one of the Upper Cana,a papers,
under his own signature, argues very rlausibly,
from the fact of Morsan's having left that pro-
vince over head and ears in debt, that he dares
not show himself there, and suggests reasons why
ae has probably gone off to the wiliernesse 0f Ohio:
while it is stated in Jefferson county IN. ~
paper that it is believed that Morgan was on board
the Lady of the Lake, which was, with every soul
on board. lost in December last, on Lake Ontario.
Now amidst all these falsehoods, contradictions,
and ahsurdlties, what are we to bcieycs
From the W. r. Commercial .adrertiser, March g.

Ibelieve the reason Of single lndiyldua !, +,
whole number approved. Not desirne = ~
thought to speak dsrespectfully Of auy of 4. N
gentlemen, we must explain that we c,ns,e 1ee|
application of the word reasonn TO the mss, WV
the thing actually to be disposed Of, viz: the n,
ing Of the Senate. In political or party iaaa pn'
it is true, we can conceive how some sentls" Is"S
should think it very reasonable to give conseouep
by their votes, to print established here II ~
at the administration, right or wrong, and wla
must be admitted to have been true to its voc.ts
But even in that sense, it was lamentabIe IA =.
such men as our old friend DIcKERsoN. the ~. ae
ruptible MACON and SMITH Of South C,ral;v C;v
BENTON, of capacious mind, and CHAYDrra
blunt honesty, not to. speak Of others. rans;' "'
themselves under the standard of a new cab,'.s
cal party organization, the first object Of uha
when brought to a head, was to " improve tba ~.
dition of the press" by prescribing the ,,ati0s.,
IntellgenceT, and identifying the Senate If w.
United States with the Telegraph! The intena"s
might have been disclained, had not the vote hss
preceded by the observations of Mr.. VAN Bupvs
They gave to that vote its true character and
Mr.. VAN BUREN's remark its right interpreatoN
The force of party could no further co. Ancsn
connections. recent associations, personal attach
ments, all melted into thin air before the wand NJ
the great magician 1t is really a lamenaA,
subject Of contemplation. For their own sakp
It gricved US to see such men yielding all them.
cuations Of their hearts, along with the conyicior
OF their reason. to the grand political scheme h,
which the vote OF New York is to be secured n
the newly organized party, and, as the price Of
MIR. VAN BuREN is to be--anv thing he plea,p
This, of course, the reader will be good enough nj
understand to be our opinion, but for that oplnjm
we shall, another day, give what appear to Us d
be very substantial reasons.
To Mr.. VAN BuREN's elevation TO hioher oM,,
than he now holds, on proper principles. we should
have had no objection. In the last Pleslent,l
Election be acted throughout with frmness and
consistency: We should have been very willinru
have seen him elected Vice President at that time,
and would, indeed, if we could have promoted hb
elevation to the honorable station now occupied bs
his friend and successful competitor, Mr.. Cal.
HouN. But when he comes forward with Ne
shlbboieth OF new party in his mouth, the first
utterance of which is to strike at the independence
OF the press, we must be excused if we treat him,
he has treated US, downrighty, and without know.
ing or caring how our exposition may affect lis
feelings or his ambitious projects.


Let no one suppose, that our views Of his pro-.
jects, and those of the small party which he is en-
,leayoring, with practised art, to form into large
one, are founded OH the single incident in the Sc.
nate, plainly as that speaks. We have other and
much higher matter to place before our readers
hereafter. But this exposition, which has been
forced upon US By considerations not to be dis.
regarded without sacrifice of every political prin'
clple we have ever pr0esAed, involves to1 much
matter 70 be disposed Of at single sitting.


Mt Intel.

The recent discussions in Congress Of the ui.
Tor the increase of duty ON imported woollens are
yet fresh IN the memory OF our readers. To such
OF them as have reflected upon the subject the fol-
lowing paragraph will not be unwecome. 1t shows
that keen-eyed Jealousy Of our rising manufac.
tures, exists out of the United States; that those
whose interest it is that they should not be suffer
ed to increase, are watching with an intense
anxiety their progress in this country. Their Oh.
Ject IS to compel the manufacturer Of the United
states to give up the hope of competing with Brit"


sn goods = and they will rejoice to learn that in
this country they are assisted in their contest with
the american manufactured. Nat. Journal.


From the Lirerpoot Commercial, Chronicle.


From the Message of the President, il appears
that the Manufacturers of Cotton and Wuoen
Goods IN the United States are becoming very ex.
tenslyc in their operations. Mr. Adams states, %
one cause OF the deficiency in the revenue of the
United States for the current year, that the Home
Manufactures have lessened the demand for
Foreign Goods. and thus the duties on imports have
decreased. unquestonably, it is most dreadful
pohcy IN tins country to continue the execrabe
Corn Laws, and so prevent that Interchange d
commodities with other nations, which would leave
our manufacturing greatness 1nnpaired. The
Americans are on the right plan now; unless we
take American flour, she will. by duties restric!
'ic consumption OF the produce OF our looms, and
VIII carefully encourage her own. 1t is to be fear
ed that America will feel it necessary to continue
the protecting duties in favor Of her manufactures,
even i we relax somewhat the rgor of our system.
IT will be a long time before the manufactures Of
America will be enabled successfully to meet US
IN foreign markets. We are aware that very large
quantities of Calico, of the Manufacture of the
United States, have been sent to South America,
ana have, IN some places affected the sale of Brit.
lsh a manufactures; the appearance and character
o' the American article being new and different
from our own.--A week or two since merchant
IN this town received pattern of the goods; they
we're sent to Manchester, and in few days sup
Ply similar in appearance, but better in quality.
was sent on to South America, to be sold at q
price (yielding due profits to all concerned) which
would compel the manufacturer of the United
States to give up the hope Of competing with Brl'
tlsh goods. II the people of England had fair
play if the industry Of the laborer, and the mer.
chants enterprise, were not in great measure
absorbed by an intolerabe taxation, rendered stll
more oppressive by the unsettled state of our hf
nancial system, we should become truly the " envy
Of surrounding nations, and the admiration Of the
world"
MANUFACTURES

directly on you but the 4th june will be time enough
"you damned recreant, when and where you shall see
ga sprig oflocust"


We have our suspicious as TO the name OF the
writer of this ferocious threatrendered still more
ferocious by second threa. which none out masons
can undersand--and we shall take efficient mea-
snres TO detect him. II is mode Of doing things,
10 follow the strict line OF duty and he threat Of
being .Norganized," will not deter US. For a
long time we believed there was more of fiction
than reality in this business and we said little about
il. When convinced of our error, we spoke out, as
every man, and every mason, should speak. We
vndicsted the fraternity from the sweeping and un-
mcrited denunciRtons, OF excited popular assem-
bes, while we spoke in the strongest terms OF re.
probston and horror Of the perpetrators OF the sup
posed crime. We shall continue to do so, when
ever our public duty requires US to speak.


Another days delay in the publication Of the
foregoing article has brought an additional arti-
Gle which it is necessary to copy. II is the follow
ing note from TWO OF The delegates TO the Lewiston
Convention, which fully acquils the late MIR, Cha
pin OF having participated in the crime Of killing
Morgan, il such crime was committed. II seems,
moreover, that after all the information obtained
Lewiston was Of an " unsatisfactory nature"


The undersigned attended at Lewiston the 25th ult
as delegates from the Rochester committee to investigate
the circumstances of the abduction OF Capt William Nor
gan During the examination of the undersigned Lewis
ton some information OF unsatisfactory character
to their knowledge, duplicating Mr. Chaplin of Buffalo
in the affair tending to show hs, he present at fort
Niagara on the night Of the 18th Sept last This nforma
on was not intended for the public eye until something
certain could be sscertaned The information how
having been alluded in private letter. afterwards
made public, contrary to the intentions Of ue writer the
undersigned deem their duty 10 state that from several
afdavits submitted to them, they convinced that Mr.
Seth Chaplin Of Buffalo, deceased, could have
been present at Fort Niagara the time above mentioned
The undersigned therefore consider it due to the family
and friends Of Mr. Seth Chaplin thus publicly state that
as far they have ascertaned, he is no way implicated
in that unhappy transaction.


FREDERICK F. BACKUS,


SAMUEL WORKS.


Rochester, Feb. 90, 1897.

NEW YonK, March 8.

SIGNS OF THE TIMEs-It is known, We believe
to our readers, that have never accorded in the
doctrine. that party spirit, in free Government
IS dangerous to the public interest. 1t has always
been our opinion on the contrary, that the exist.
ence OF party spirit, to certain extent, is greatly
to be preferred to the calm of despotism, whether
that despotism be one of opinion or of physical
strength. An opposition to the measures of Go
yernment, when founded upon principle, is entitled
to respect and consideration, even from the Admin
lstration to Which it is opposed. When founded
upon different principles, or rather upon no prn-
clple at all, but that OF combination to obtain pos
session OF the offices and patronage of Govern
ment, it is still useful; because ii induces caution
and regard for public opinion, the part Of those
who administer the Government, which cannot fail
to serve and protect the public interest. We must
have good reasons, however, before ws engage in
an oppposltion To an existing administration, Of
the nature first above stated, and we never Will,
under any circumstances, engage in one Of the ma
ture last described


With respect to the present Administration Of
the Government. it will be remembered by all who
read this Journal, that, at the time of its induction
to office; on its subsequent organization; and at
later date, we have expressed conviction that
the election Of the President had been honestly
made, and that the President had acted wisely.
and with exclusive regard to the public intel est,
and to the circumstances of his election, in the
appointment Of the Officers who preside over
the different Departments Of the Government, and
represent our country abroad. More recently, we
have had occasion to say, that. Judging the Admin
istration by its measures, we believed, for any
thing that could see, that the election of Prpsi-
dent by the House Of Representatives resulted
beneficlaly to the country. there being more 10
approve than to disapprove in the measures Of this
Government. We have yet seen nothing a. change
this opinion. F." Unwarped by party rage" or even
by personal attachments; wholv unconnectel
With the Executive Administration Of the General
Government free from anv engagement UNDER
standing, or alliance, with any party, or party
men, this IS the unbiased dictate Of our deliberate
Judgment


This sentiment, such as we have heretofore ey.
pressed it, We now repeat, with entire Difference
TO the opinions of others. We have not sought to
seduce others to our opinions still less have we
denounced those who have come to different con-
cusions, or acted upon different principles, from
us.


Recent circumstances, however, have disclosed
the existence OF an organized Opposition to the
present Administration, the object Of which is to
put it down, right or wrong. The first open ap-
Pllcation OF this principle having heea made, con
temporaneousy with its avowal, to us personally,
occasoned us no little surprise. It is with main
indeed, we find ourselves obliged to direct the A.
tenton Of our readers to some features Of the
scheme. By which the Machiayelian principles Of
a yesy few individuals are sought to be made the
ruls of action for great Peope--of the scheme,
in The prosecution of which, public utility, faithful
services, and acknow lodged integrity, are to be
sacrificed to the Moloch Of party of the scheme
by the successful operation of which this Admins
tration is, in the language Of highly respectable
member of the party, to be "put down, though il
be as pure as the Angels which stand at the right
hand of the throne of God ~
We shall endeavor to say nothing personally Of
fensive to any human being in our present expos
ton Of this matter; but we should be treacherou.
WnShinmt0n. Mnrch Z

to the great national Interests Of which "c az ar
proud Of being the advocates-we shou'u pe 'ai'n'


less to our readers, who look to US for the develop


ment Of nassinp eyents-if we did not speak PLAIN
Ilv what we know, and Disclose frankly what we
believe II this be offensive to the preJuaices oI


convictions Of any OF our readers, we s'a' rcsse
it. But, circnmsanced as we are, the supPressioh


of truth, on such subject, rs equiValehl 70 .e *


pression of falsehood. If we were to withhold


What we know and believe, on matter so vital to


tfie great interests Of country as mat we are


about to open, our daily paper would be dal'y
lie to the community. !,
| With these preliminary remarks, we invite the


attention of our readers to the vote, IN the senate


of the United States, on Thursday last, Tor rrln-
ter to that body. The occasion was IN itself an


unimportant one, wholly unworthy oil special no.


tice, and to which we certainly should never nave
invited the attention of our readers, out ior the


organization which it for the first time disclosed,


and for the principles openly ayowed on that occa-
sion by the Honorable MARTIN VAN BuREN, an


eminent Senator from the State of New York, who


has earned the distinction of being brought into


this bold relief, by presenting himself. on that DAY.


as the spokesman OF the party OF which we sfa'l


take the freedom to consider him the head and re-


presentative if he be not both its parent and ITS


guardian. Of that Senator, we should be the last


to speak with personal disrespect. With talents


enough to be a great man, he has the manners OF
gentleman, and an enviable private character. 1t


is only of his political principles, his notions Of


party discipline, and the manner in which he has
brought them both to bear upon the present state
of public affairs, that we mean to speak.


On the occasion to which we have already refer


red, Mr.. VAN BuREs made the following remarks


which we're carefully noted down BY our Reporter.
and will not be denied or letracted


III Lod ,f n, ~ liz
interest might be promoted, The condition v The Press
ueA here Mroughohe country improved and respect for
the Senate and accuracy in the publication OF the Proceed
ings of the Sen ate better secured by udcous revision
of the laws relative 10 the public printing large. at


convenient season he hoped the subject would be
revised and he promised himself the best results m such
provision as the nature Of The subject was susceptible Of"


Now, to :. the revision of the aws,'' we have
not the slightest possible objection nor do we care
how the Senate shall think proper to Lave its
printing done for the future, so it be decently


done. II is to the aroeed object Of this proposed re-
vision, that we take exception. We throw out Of
view the !" accuracy in the publication Of the Pro
ceedings,' as motive for the proposed revision.
because every one, who knows any thing about it,
knows that this suggestion is thrown III to make
up light weight; pass by also the " respect for
the Senate,' in which every man OF sense knows,
andevery man OF candor will acknowledge, we ehave
never been in any manner deficient: and, leaving
autH dTSulHcHtS tO th0Se VINO can swallow Inefll.
we enter our protest against the doctrine embraced
III the other part of his remarks, that tile condition
IF the Press is to be regulated not only here. but
: throughout the United States by any vote 1t thr
Senate, or by any legislation Of both Houses Of
Congress combined. We protest against this re-
yiva OF the odious principle Of the old Sedtion
Law, viz the right Of party to protect itself by
or form the Press through the agency o legislation
by Congress.


1t was, indeed, somewhat an extraordinary CO.
incidence, that whilst, in the other House, the
conduct ot the Secretary Of State was arraiuned
Tor changing some Of the Publishers of the Laws.
as though he had committed an offence meritins
impeachment, it should be gravely proposed, as
desiderntam in the Senate, that the Press, not on
here, but throughout the country, should be renua.
ted by the distribution OF the Public Printing, with
a view to imprnring the condition of the Press. .
What has been deemed objectionable i'll Secreta
ry OF State, seems to have been thought by the |
Senator to be perfectly fair in party in
one branch Of the Legislature, upon whose predom-
nance IN both branches of the next Congress the
most confident calculations are made-wth what
accuracy tlme will show.


The honorable Senator ought to be VEL, aware
OF tie utter tutilly OF all attempts to organize the
phbllc press. Its conductors are made of sterner
stun than to be brought down upon their knees
with one accord, to worship any idol Of party which
ne maT choose to set up. There are thousand
OF these individuals. many Of whom would not only
part with the paltry profit flowing from paltry pat
rolase, but even with liberty, life itself, sooner
than with the right Of private Judgment, Of which
his notion Of party discipline requires the absolute
surrender. Nor can the press be chastset, any
more tnan il can be bought or sold. The idea of
thus operating upon the press cannot live in the
pure atmosphere Of pablie opinion, however it may
De cherished by passion prejudice. Much NAV
be effected, we kHow, in regard to the press, by
party organization whiting tie limits Of single
state : we have seen examples Of that, as we have
OF the elect OF similar organization in the

From, the ". r. Commercial .adrertiser, March 9.


MORGAN.-The following remarks were pre-.
pared to accompany the letter of Capt. Brandt,
published last evening, but were excluded for want
of room AS at this distance from the circle in
which he moves, his character may not be distinct
ly known, Ito quote the Editor of the Quebec
Mercury,) it is but justice, since his name has
been brought forward, to say, that MIR. Brandt is
generally respected and there need be no hesita-
ton in believing what he says lie is well edu-
Gated young man, and was as much esteemed by
the Officers Of the Division of His Majesty's Ar
my, with which he served during the last Amer
ican war, for his gentlemanly manners IN society,
as for his courage and humanity in the field. Mr..
Brandt some time ago visited England, and while
there surprised the public and the poet, Thomas
Campbell, by letter, as crcditable to his tllial

Mr.. Campbell, in the beautiful but unfaithful mar

the murIerers. But the story proved not to be
true: We were told that traces of blood &c.
were found IN Fort Niagara But tnat IS NOT true


We were told that Capt. Brandt was consulted
about killing him, or putting him away; and that
was not true. We have all along been told, more
over, that there was conspiracy originally, to

false accusation OF larceny: And now jury has
solemnly declared that that story was likewise un-
true. And one of the men convicted at Canaan

while it is stated in Jefferson county IN. ~
paper that it is believed that Morgan was on board
the Lady of the Lake, which was, with every soul
on board. lost in December last, on Lake Ontario.
Now amidst all these falsehoods, contradictions,
and ahsurdlties, what are we to bcieycs

thought to speak dsrespectfully Of auy of 4. N

ing Of the Senate. In political or party iaaa pn'
it is true, we can conceive how some sentls" Is"S
should think it very reasonable to give conseouep
by their votes, to print established here II ~
at the administration, right or wrong, and wla
must be admitted to have been true to its voc.ts
But even in that sense, it was lamentabIe IA =.
such men as our old friend DIcKERsoN. the ~. ae
ruptible MACON and SMITH Of South C,ral;v C;v
BENTON, of capacious mind, and CHAYDrra
blunt honesty, not to. speak Of others. rans;' "'
themselves under the standard of a new cab,'.s

when brought to a head, was to " improve tba ~.
dition of the press" by prescribing the ,,ati0s.,
IntellgenceT, and identifying the Senate If w.
United States with the Telegraph! The intena"s
might have been disclained, had not the vote hss
preceded by the observations of Mr.. VAN Bupvs
They gave to that vote its true character and
Mr.. VAN BUREN's remark its right interpreatoN
The force of party could no further co. Ancsn
connections. recent associations, personal attach
ments, all melted into thin air before the wand NJ
the great magician 1t is really a lamenaA,
subject Of contemplation. For their own sakp
It gricved US to see such men yielding all them.
cuations Of their hearts, along with the conyicior
OF their reason. to the grand political scheme h,
which the vote OF New York is to be secured n
the newly organized party, and, as the price Of
MIR. VAN BuREN is to be--anv thing he plea,p
This, of course, the reader will be good enough nj
understand to be our opinion, but for that oplnjm
we shall, another day, give what appear to Us d
be very substantial reasons.
To Mr.. VAN BuREN's elevation TO hioher oM,,
than he now holds, on proper principles. we should
have had no objection. In the last Pleslent,l
Election be acted throughout with frmness and
consistency: We should have been very willinru
have seen him elected Vice President at that time,
and would, indeed, if we could have promoted hb
elevation to the honorable station now occupied bs
his friend and successful competitor, Mr.. Cal.
HouN. But when he comes forward with Ne
shlbboieth OF new party in his mouth, the first
utterance of which is to strike at the independence
OF the press, we must be excused if we treat him,
he has treated US, downrighty, and without know.
ing or caring how our exposition may affect lis
feelings or his ambitious projects.


Let no one suppose, that our views Of his pro-.
jects, and those of the small party which he is en-
,leayoring, with practised art, to form into large
one, are founded OH the single incident in the Sc.
nate, plainly as that speaks. We have other and
much higher matter to place before our readers
hereafter. But this exposition, which has been
forced upon US By considerations not to be dis.
regarded without sacrifice of every political prin'
clple we have ever pr0esAed, involves to1 much
matter 70 be disposed Of at single sitting.


Mt Intel.

full articles.headline: MANUFACTURES
full articles.article:
The recent discussions in Congress Of the ui.
Tor the increase of duty ON imported woollens are
yet fresh IN the memory OF our readers. To such
OF them as have reflected upon the subject the fol-
lowing paragraph will not be unwecome. 1t shows
that keen-eyed Jealousy Of our rising manufac.
tures, exists out of the United States; that those
whose interest it is that they should not be suffer
ed to increase, are watching with an intense
anxiety their progress in this country. Their Oh.
Ject IS to compel the manufacturer Of the United
states to give up the hope of competing with Brit"


sn goods = and they will rejoice to learn that in
this country they are assisted in their contest with
the american manufactured. Nat. Journal.


From the Lirerpoot Commercial, Chronicle.


From the Message of the President, il appears
that the Manufacturers of Cotton and Wuoen
Goods IN the United States are becoming very ex.
tenslyc in their operations. Mr. Adams states, %
one cause OF the deficiency in the revenue of the
United States for the current year, that the Home
Manufactures have lessened the demand for
Foreign Goods. and thus the duties on imports have
decreased. unquestonably, it is most dreadful
pohcy IN tins country to continue the execrabe
Corn Laws, and so prevent that Interchange d
commodities with other nations, which would leave
our manufacturing greatness 1nnpaired. The
Americans are on the right plan now; unless we
take American flour, she will. by duties restric!
'ic consumption OF the produce OF our looms, and
VIII carefully encourage her own. 1t is to be fear
ed that America will feel it necessary to continue
the protecting duties in favor Of her manufactures,
even i we relax somewhat the rgor of our system.
IT will be a long time before the manufactures Of
America will be enabled successfully to meet US
IN foreign markets. We are aware that very large
quantities of Calico, of the Manufacture of the
United States, have been sent to South America,
ana have, IN some places affected the sale of Brit.
lsh a manufactures; the appearance and character
o' the American article being new and different
from our own.--A week or two since merchant
IN this town received pattern of the goods; they
we're sent to Manchester, and in few days sup
Ply similar in appearance, but better in quality.
was sent on to South America, to be sold at q
price (yielding due profits to all concerned) which
would compel the manufacturer of the United
States to give up the hope Of competing with Brl'
tlsh goods. II the people of England had fair
play if the industry Of the laborer, and the mer.
chants enterprise, were not in great measure
absorbed by an intolerabe taxation, rendered stll
more oppressive by the unsettled state of our hf
nancial system, we should become truly the " envy
Of surrounding nations, and the admiration Of the
world"

directly on you but the 4th june will be time enough
"you damned recreant, when and where you shall see
ga sprig oflocust"


We have our suspicious as TO the name OF the
writer of this ferocious threatrendered still more
ferocious by second threa. which none out masons
can undersand--and we shall take efficient mea-
snres TO detect him. II is mode Of doing things,
10 follow the strict line OF duty and he threat Of
being .Norganized," will not deter US. For a
long time we believed there was more of fiction
than reality in this business and we said little about
il. When convinced of our error, we spoke out, as
every man, and every mason, should speak. We
vndicsted the fraternity from the sweeping and un-
mcrited denunciRtons, OF excited popular assem-
bes, while we spoke in the strongest terms OF re.
probston and horror Of the perpetrators OF the sup
posed crime. We shall continue to do so, when
ever our public duty requires US to speak.


Another days delay in the publication Of the
foregoing article has brought an additional arti-
Gle which it is necessary to copy. II is the follow
ing note from TWO OF The delegates TO the Lewiston
Convention, which fully acquils the late MIR, Cha
pin OF having participated in the crime Of killing
Morgan, il such crime was committed. II seems,
moreover, that after all the information obtained
Lewiston was Of an " unsatisfactory nature"


The undersigned attended at Lewiston the 25th ult
as delegates from the Rochester committee to investigate
the circumstances of the abduction OF Capt William Nor
gan During the examination of the undersigned Lewis
ton some information OF unsatisfactory character
to their knowledge, duplicating Mr. Chaplin of Buffalo
in the affair tending to show hs, he present at fort
Niagara on the night Of the 18th Sept last This nforma
on was not intended for the public eye until something
certain could be sscertaned The information how
having been alluded in private letter. afterwards
made public, contrary to the intentions Of ue writer the
undersigned deem their duty 10 state that from several
afdavits submitted to them, they convinced that Mr.
Seth Chaplin Of Buffalo, deceased, could have
been present at Fort Niagara the time above mentioned
The undersigned therefore consider it due to the family
and friends Of Mr. Seth Chaplin thus publicly state that
as far they have ascertaned, he is no way implicated
in that unhappy transaction.


FREDERICK F. BACKUS,


SAMUEL WORKS.


Rochester, Feb. 90, 1897.

full articles.headline: WnShinmt0n. Mnrch Z
full articles.article:
SIGNS OF THE TIMEs-It is known, We believe
to our readers, that have never accorded in the
doctrine. that party spirit, in free Government
IS dangerous to the public interest. 1t has always
been our opinion on the contrary, that the exist.
ence OF party spirit, to certain extent, is greatly
to be preferred to the calm of despotism, whether
that despotism be one of opinion or of physical
strength. An opposition to the measures of Go
yernment, when founded upon principle, is entitled
to respect and consideration, even from the Admin
lstration to Which it is opposed. When founded
upon different principles, or rather upon no prn-
clple at all, but that OF combination to obtain pos
session OF the offices and patronage of Govern
ment, it is still useful; because ii induces caution
and regard for public opinion, the part Of those
who administer the Government, which cannot fail
to serve and protect the public interest. We must
have good reasons, however, before ws engage in
an oppposltion To an existing administration, Of
the nature first above stated, and we never Will,
under any circumstances, engage in one Of the ma
ture last described


With respect to the present Administration Of
the Government. it will be remembered by all who
read this Journal, that, at the time of its induction
to office; on its subsequent organization; and at
later date, we have expressed conviction that
the election Of the President had been honestly
made, and that the President had acted wisely.
and with exclusive regard to the public intel est,
and to the circumstances of his election, in the
appointment Of the Officers who preside over
the different Departments Of the Government, and
represent our country abroad. More recently, we
have had occasion to say, that. Judging the Admin
istration by its measures, we believed, for any
thing that could see, that the election of Prpsi-
dent by the House Of Representatives resulted
beneficlaly to the country. there being more 10
approve than to disapprove in the measures Of this
Government. We have yet seen nothing a. change
this opinion. F." Unwarped by party rage" or even
by personal attachments; wholv unconnectel
With the Executive Administration Of the General
Government free from anv engagement UNDER
standing, or alliance, with any party, or party
men, this IS the unbiased dictate Of our deliberate
Judgment


This sentiment, such as we have heretofore ey.
pressed it, We now repeat, with entire Difference
TO the opinions of others. We have not sought to
seduce others to our opinions still less have we
denounced those who have come to different con-
cusions, or acted upon different principles, from
us.


Recent circumstances, however, have disclosed
the existence OF an organized Opposition to the
present Administration, the object Of which is to
put it down, right or wrong. The first open ap-
Pllcation OF this principle having heea made, con
temporaneousy with its avowal, to us personally,
occasoned us no little surprise. It is with main
indeed, we find ourselves obliged to direct the A.
tenton Of our readers to some features Of the
scheme. By which the Machiayelian principles Of
a yesy few individuals are sought to be made the
ruls of action for great Peope--of the scheme,
in The prosecution of which, public utility, faithful
services, and acknow lodged integrity, are to be
sacrificed to the Moloch Of party of the scheme
by the successful operation of which this Admins
tration is, in the language Of highly respectable
member of the party, to be "put down, though il
be as pure as the Angels which stand at the right
hand of the throne of God ~
We shall endeavor to say nothing personally Of
fensive to any human being in our present expos
ton Of this matter; but we should be treacherou.

to the great national Interests Of which "c az ar
proud Of being the advocates-we shou'u pe 'ai'n'


less to our readers, who look to US for the develop


ment Of nassinp eyents-if we did not speak PLAIN
Ilv what we know, and Disclose frankly what we
believe II this be offensive to the preJuaices oI


convictions Of any OF our readers, we s'a' rcsse
it. But, circnmsanced as we are, the supPressioh


of truth, on such subject, rs equiValehl 70 .e *


pression of falsehood. If we were to withhold


What we know and believe, on matter so vital to


tfie great interests Of country as mat we are


about to open, our daily paper would be dal'y
lie to the community. !,
| With these preliminary remarks, we invite the


attention of our readers to the vote, IN the senate


of the United States, on Thursday last, Tor rrln-
ter to that body. The occasion was IN itself an


unimportant one, wholly unworthy oil special no.


tice, and to which we certainly should never nave
invited the attention of our readers, out ior the


organization which it for the first time disclosed,


and for the principles openly ayowed on that occa-
sion by the Honorable MARTIN VAN BuREN, an


eminent Senator from the State of New York, who


has earned the distinction of being brought into


this bold relief, by presenting himself. on that DAY.


as the spokesman OF the party OF which we sfa'l


take the freedom to consider him the head and re-


presentative if he be not both its parent and ITS


guardian. Of that Senator, we should be the last


to speak with personal disrespect. With talents


enough to be a great man, he has the manners OF
gentleman, and an enviable private character. 1t


is only of his political principles, his notions Of


party discipline, and the manner in which he has
brought them both to bear upon the present state
of public affairs, that we mean to speak.


On the occasion to which we have already refer


red, Mr.. VAN BuREs made the following remarks


which we're carefully noted down BY our Reporter.
and will not be denied or letracted


III Lod ,f n, ~ liz
interest might be promoted, The condition v The Press
ueA here Mroughohe country improved and respect for
the Senate and accuracy in the publication OF the Proceed
ings of the Sen ate better secured by udcous revision
of the laws relative 10 the public printing large. at


convenient season he hoped the subject would be
revised and he promised himself the best results m such
provision as the nature Of The subject was susceptible Of"


Now, to :. the revision of the aws,'' we have
not the slightest possible objection nor do we care
how the Senate shall think proper to Lave its
printing done for the future, so it be decently


done. II is to the aroeed object Of this proposed re-
vision, that we take exception. We throw out Of
view the !" accuracy in the publication Of the Pro
ceedings,' as motive for the proposed revision.
because every one, who knows any thing about it,
knows that this suggestion is thrown III to make
up light weight; pass by also the " respect for
the Senate,' in which every man OF sense knows,
andevery man OF candor will acknowledge, we ehave
never been in any manner deficient: and, leaving
autH dTSulHcHtS tO th0Se VINO can swallow Inefll.
we enter our protest against the doctrine embraced
III the other part of his remarks, that tile condition
IF the Press is to be regulated not only here. but
: throughout the United States by any vote 1t thr
Senate, or by any legislation Of both Houses Of
Congress combined. We protest against this re-
yiva OF the odious principle Of the old Sedtion
Law, viz the right Of party to protect itself by
or form the Press through the agency o legislation
by Congress.


1t was, indeed, somewhat an extraordinary CO.
incidence, that whilst, in the other House, the
conduct ot the Secretary Of State was arraiuned
Tor changing some Of the Publishers of the Laws.
as though he had committed an offence meritins
impeachment, it should be gravely proposed, as
desiderntam in the Senate, that the Press, not on
here, but throughout the country, should be renua.
ted by the distribution OF the Public Printing, with
a view to imprnring the condition of the Press. .
What has been deemed objectionable i'll Secreta
ry OF State, seems to have been thought by the |
Senator to be perfectly fair in party in
one branch Of the Legislature, upon whose predom-
nance IN both branches of the next Congress the
most confident calculations are made-wth what
accuracy tlme will show.


The honorable Senator ought to be VEL, aware
OF tie utter tutilly OF all attempts to organize the
phbllc press. Its conductors are made of sterner
stun than to be brought down upon their knees
with one accord, to worship any idol Of party which
ne maT choose to set up. There are thousand
OF these individuals. many Of whom would not only
part with the paltry profit flowing from paltry pat
rolase, but even with liberty, life itself, sooner
than with the right Of private Judgment, Of which
his notion Of party discipline requires the absolute
surrender. Nor can the press be chastset, any
more tnan il can be bought or sold. The idea of
thus operating upon the press cannot live in the
pure atmosphere Of pablie opinion, however it may
De cherished by passion prejudice. Much NAV
be effected, we kHow, in regard to the press, by
party organization whiting tie limits Of single
state : we have seen examples Of that, as we have
OF the elect OF similar organization in the
de puaI fupnt nf fLn
